definition: *sample form (1: single phase(bulk),2: multi phase (bulk),3: single crystal(bulk) ,4:film,5:film(single))
common formula of materials
The recommended superconducting critical temperature ($T_c$) specific to the sample.
The conventional or informal name for a material's crystal structure, as commonly used within the condensed matter physics community, particularly as it relates to superconducting materials.
The length of the unit cell along the c-axis, critical to the crystal structure in condensed matter physics and superconductivity.
The crystallographic parameter 'a' defining the length of the unit cell along the 'a' direction.
The foundational substances used for the synthesis of a specific superconducting material.
The length of the unit cell edge along the 'b' direction, which defines the crystal structure geometry in condensed matter materials like superconductors.
The critical temperature (Tc) of a superconductor as determined by the abrupt change in magnetic susceptibility, which signifies the onset of perfect diamagnetism and the superconducting state.
The specific technique or process used to create or synthesize the material sample.
The critical temperature ($T_c$) of a superconductor, measured at the onset of superconductivity (where electrical resistivity R = 100%).

The variation of the lattice constant 'a' of a crystal structure with changes in temperature.

definition: The electrical resistivity of a single-crystal material at room temperature (RT), measured with the current density (J) parallel to the crystal's ab-plane.

The isotope shift coefficient ($\alpha$) quantifying the dependence of the superconducting transition temperature ($T_c$) on the atomic mass ($M$) of the constituent elements, where $T_c \propto M^{-\alpha}$.

property_name: DTC = Tc - Tc0 for isotope element
definition: The change in superconducting critical temperature due to the presence of an isotope element.

property_name: alpha in Tc = A * M^(-alpha), isotope effect
definition: The exponent $\alpha$ relating the critical temperature ($T_c$) of a superconductor to the isotopic mass ($M$) as $T_c \propto M^{-\alpha}$, defining the magnitude of the isotope effect.

definition: The electrical resistivity of a single crystal measured at 77 Kelvin, with the current density (J) applied parallel to the crystal's ab-plane.

A technique used to determine the superconducting critical temperature ($T_c$), categorized by methods such as: 1. magnetization, 2. AC susceptibility, 3. resistivity, 4. heat capacity, 5. tunneling, 6. infrared spectroscopy, 7. thermal conductivity, 8. Raman spectroscopy, 9. nuclear magnetic resonance, 10. surface impedance, 11. neutron diffraction, 12. photoemission spectroscopy, 13. microwave transmission, or 14. others.

Curie constant
The source material used for the synthesis of a superconducting material.
The material's ability to conduct heat, measured at a temperature of 300 Kelvin.
The number assigned to a space group, found in the International Tables for Crystallography, which defines the symmetry of a crystal structure.

The temperature range where a superconductor's electrical resistivity drops from 90% to 10% during the transition to the superconducting state.

property_name: Hall coefficient at 300 K for single, H//ab-plane
definition: The measure of how free charge carriers in a single-crystal material respond to a magnetic field applied parallel to the ab-plane, specifically measured at 300 K.

property_name: Hall coefficient at 300 K for single, H//c-axis
definition: The Hall coefficient measured at 300 K for a single-crystal material, specifically indicating the response of free charge carriers to a magnetic field applied parallel to the c-axis.

property_name: penetration depth at 0 K for single crystal for H⊥ab-plane
definition: The magnetic field penetration distance in a single crystal superconductor at zero temperature, measured with the field perpendicular to the ab-plane, reflecting the superfluid density along the c-axis.
The change in the lattice constant 'a' (a crystallographic dimension) of a material in response to applied external pressure.
The rate at which the lattice constant 'b' of a crystal structure changes in response to applied external pressure.
The change in the lattice constant 'c' (one of the unit cell dimensions) of a crystal structure in response to applied pressure.

property_name: resistivity at 4.2 K for single crystal for J//ab-plane
definition: Electrical resistivity measured at 4.2 Kelvin for a single-crystal material when the current density (J) flows parallel to the ab-plane of the crystal structure. This value typically represents the residual or normal-state resistivity just above the superconducting transition temperature.

property_name: resistivity at 4.2 K for single crystal for J//c-axis
definition: The electrical resistivity of a single crystal, measured at 4.2 K, with the current density (J) directed parallel to the c-axis, used to study fundamental electronic transport properties at cryogenic temperatures.

The highest pressure applied to a sample in an experiment.
